creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
description: bowl, octagonal, eight reserve panels each with Dutchman in various poses; blue underglaze and polychromed overglaze on porcelain. Marked on bottom
medium: Imari ware; porcelain with underglaze blue and overglaze enamels
text: When political turmoil in China prevented Dutch traders from filling European orders for decorative porcelains, they turned to the budding porcelain industry in Japan. Between the mid-seventeeth and mid-eighteenth century, vast quantities of brilliantly colored wares were exported abroad. At the same time, the Japanese themselves also developed a taste for porcelain. This bowl was undoubtedly made for the domestic market as it features amusing depictions of exotic foreigners.
title: Bowl with Dutchmen
